courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Analysis I
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to linear structures and analysis covering fundamental concepts and techniques involving mathematical proofs for metric/ topological results in the one-dimensional and higher dimensional Euclidean spaces as well as in function spaces.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Define rigorously and comprehend the concepts in linear algebra and analysis.
• Logically prove basic results in linear algebra and elementary analysis.
• Understand the rationale of the mathematical conditions and conclusions of the results involved.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics may be chosen amongst:
• linear structure (including infinite dimensional)
• topology of finite dimensional linear space
• topology of space of continuous functions
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the teaching materials
courses.recommended_readings:
• K. R. Davidson, A.P. Donsig, Real Analysis with Real Applications
• T.A. Garrity, All the Mathematics You Missed
• C.C. Pugh, Real Mathematical Analysis
• Patrick M. Fitzpatrick, Advanced Calculus

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Linear Analysis
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to linear structures and various concepts of limits/convergence in analysis especially in the context of Euclidean/Hilbert/Banach spaces as well as the Lebesgue integration spaces.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to linear structures and various concepts of limits/convergence in analysis especially in the context of Euclidean/Hilbert/Banach spaces as well as the Lebesgue integration spaces.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by the course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings: J. Muscat, Functional Analysis, Springer (2014)

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Analysis II
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The prerequisite of this course is the mathematical contents of Analysis I. The course is intended to provide basic and fundamental knowledge of modern analysis involving limits and various notions of convergence in the context of metirc/normed vector/Hilbert spaces as well as the vector Lp spaces.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Define rigorously and comprehend the advanced concepts in analysis.
• Logically prove basic results in analysis.
• Understand the rationale of the mathematical conditions and conclusions of the results in analysis.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics may be chosen amongst:
• complete metric spaces
• Banach/Hilbert spaces
• Lp-norms
• approximation theory
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the teaching materials
courses.recommended_readings:
• K. R. Davidson, A.P. Donsig, Real Analysis with Real Applications
• T.A. Garrity, All the Mathematics You Missed
• C.C. Pugh, Real Mathematical Analysis
• Patrick M. Fitzpatrick, Advanced Calculus

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Algebra and Geometry
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is an introduction to commutative algebra, in particular polynomial rings of one and several variables, their ideals and the associated varieties. The Hilbert basis theorem and Groebner bases algorithms are included.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To acquire and understand basic concepts in polynomial rings and commutative algebra.

2. To use ideas in algebra to study geometric problems.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics includes commutative rings, integral domains, ideals, prime and irreducible ideals, algebraic varieties, Noetherian rings, dimension and Hilbert basis theorem.
courses.required_readings: Chosen by instructor from the Recommended Readings below.
courses.recommended_readings:
An introductory course in commutative algebra: Chatters, A. W., Oxford.

Ideals, Varieties, and Algorithms: Davis Cox, John Little, Donal O’Shea, Springer Verlag

Undergraduate Algebraic Geometry: Miles Reid, Cambridge University Press

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Differential and Algebraic Methods in Geometry
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to the geometry of curves and surfaces in 3 dimensional Euclidean space. The fundamental group and its application in the classification of closed surfaces will also be discussed.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Apply analytical methods to study curves and surfaces.
• Apply techniques of differential geometry to describe the curvatures of curves and surfaces.
• Understand the interplay between local and global geometry.
• Classify closed surfaces using fundamental group.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics includes curvatures of curves, Frenet frame, first and second fundamental forms, Gaussian curvature, Gauss map, Gauss’s Theorema Egregium, Gauss-Bonnet theorem, fundamental group and classification of closed surfaces etc.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the teaching materials
courses.recommended_readings:
• Pressley, Andrew: Elementary Differential Geometry, Springer Verlag
• John McCleary: Geometry from a Differentiable Viewpoint, Cambridge University Press

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Fourier Analysis
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the theory and applications of Fourier analysis, intended for students of the MSc programme of Mathematics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• have an awareness of the abstract mathematical concepts in the field of Fourier analysis.
• appreciate the applications of Fourier analysis in the study of physical phenomena.
• appreciate how the study of Fourier series by mathematicians led to the development of some profound mathematical ideas.
• have a knowledge and understanding one or more of the following topic areas: Dirichlet’s Theorem, solution of boundary value problems using Fourier series, Gibbs’ phenomenon, orthogonal functions, Bessel’s Inequality and Parseval’s Identity, Fourier transform.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics may be chosen amongst:
• Fourier series, trigonometric series
• Fourier series solutions of boundary value problems
• orthogonal functions
• Fourier transform
• applications of Fourier analysis in various areas in mathematics
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the teaching materials
courses.recommended_readings:
• Brown and Churchill: Fourier Series and Boundary Value Problems
• Asmar: Partial Differential Equations with Fourier Series and Boundary Value Problems
• Young: An Introduction to Hilbert Space

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Topics in Number Theory
courses.description: Divisibility of integers, theory of primes, fundamental theorem of Arithmetic, basic sieve methods, modular arithmetic, diophantine equations, cryptography, number theoretic functions, primitive roots, the quadratic reciprocity law, elliptic curves and other topics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Understand the basic idea and the proofs of some basic theorems in number theory
• Applications of number theory, e.g. cryptography
• Acquire background knowledge in more advanced topics such as analytic number theory, algebraic number theory, etc.
courses.course_syllabus: Divisibility of integers, theory of primes, Fundamental theorem of Arithmetic, basic sieve methods, modular arithmetic, diophantine equations, cryptography, number theoretic functions, primitive roots, the quadratic reciprocity law, elliptic curves and other topics.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the teaching materials
courses.recommended_readings:
• Elementary Number Theory by D.M. Burton, Mcgraw-Hill, 7th ed.
• The Theory of Numbers, by I. Niven, H.S. Zuckerman, H.L. Montgomery, John Wiley & Sons Inc, 5th ed.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Topics in Geometry
courses.description: This course is intended to provide a brief, but solid, modern introduction to various basic geometries using analytic methods.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Define and distinguish the usual concepts used in various basic geometries
• Logically prove basic statements in various basic geometries
• Calculate various geometry quantities and solve problems in various basic geometries
• Appreciate the rationale and impact of various basic geometries to human development in science and technology
courses.course_syllabus:
• Geometric transformations,
• Mobius Geometry,
• Hyperbolic Geometry,
• Elliptic Geometry.
• Quaternions and Euclidean Solid Geometry (optional)
• Pseudo-Euclidean Geometry (optional)
• Hyperbolic and Elliptic Solid Geometry (optional)
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the teaching materials
courses.recommended_readings: Michael Henle, “Modern Geometries, Non-Euclidean, Projective, and Discrete” 2nd Ed., Prentice Hall

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Topics in Differential Equations
courses.description: This course aims to provide with students a short and yet concise introduction to ordinary differential equations (O.D.E.). We will cover the conventional topics such as classifications of O.D.E., first order equations, linear second and higher order equations. If time permits, we may indicate heuristically how existence and uniqueness theorems are to be proved. Other optional topics may include: power series method, Frobenius’ series method, two-point boundary value problems, Sturm-Liouville problems, non-linear systems.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:

• Determine the type of differential equations according to order, linearity vs. non-linearity etc.

• Acquire simple techniques to solve first and second order equations of various types;
• Acquire rudiments of more advanced topics such as existence and uniqueness theorems, Frobenius’ series method, Sturm-Liouville problems, non-linear systems.
courses.required_readings: Suggested by instructor.
courses.recommended_readings:
• W. E. Boyce, R. C. DiPrima, Elementary Differential Equations and Boundary Value Problems

• G. F. Simmons, S. G. Krantz, Differential Equations: Theory, Techniques, and Practice

• D. A. Sanchez, Differential Equations, an Eclectic Tour

• W. Walter, Ordinary Differential Equations

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Probability Theory
courses.description: This is a course designed for the M.Sc. program. It aims to provide a basic but rigorous (both in theory and in applications) course in elementary probability theory.
courses.course_syllabus: Axioms of Probability, Random Variables, Combinatorial Methods, Conditional Probability and Independence, Distribution Functions, Discrete Random Variables, Special Discrete Distributions, Continuous Random Variables, Special Continuous Distributions, Bivariate Distributions, Multivariate Distributions, More Expectations and Variances, Moment Generating Functions, Sums of Independent Random Variables, Central Limit Theorems, Laws of Large Numbers, Random Walks, Transition Probabilities and Markov Chains.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the teaching materials
courses.recommended_readings:
• Saeed Ghahramani, Fundamentals of Probability, 3th ed., 2005, Prentice-Hall.
• Jean Jacod, Philip Protter, Probability Essentials, 2nd Ed., 2004, Springer.
• Kai Lai Chung, Farid AitSahlia, Elementary Probability Theory: with Stochastic Processes and an Introduction to Mathematical Finance, 2003, Springer.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is an introduction to discrete mathematics; topics will be chosen from: set theory, number theory, algebraic structures, recurrence relations and generating functions, rudiments of analysis of algorithms, finite geometries, (combinatorial) design theory, coding theory, graph theory, and various methods in combinatorics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Acquire simple techniques in the methods of discrete mathematics.
• Acquire rudiments of more advanced topics, such as finite geometries, design theory, coding theory, graph theory, which has wide applications in various areas in modern science and technology.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics may be chosen amongst:
• set theory,
• number theory,
• algebraic structures,
• recurrence relations and generating functions,
• rudiments of analysis of algorithms,
• finite geometries,
• design theory,
• coding theory,
• graph theory, and
• various methods in combinatorics.
courses.required_readings: Suggested by instructor.
courses.recommended_readings:
• I. Anderson, A First Course in Discrete Mathematics
• R. J. Wilson, Introduction to Graph Theory
• D. R. Stinson, Combinatorial Designs: Constructions and Analysis
• P. J. Cameron, Combinatorics: Topics, Techniques, Algorithms
• J. H. van Lint, R. M. Wilson, A Course in Combinatorics
• D. B. West, Introduction to Graph Theory

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Complex Analysis and Its Applications
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to the analysis and applications of analytic functions on the complex plane. Emphasis will be placed on the understanding and appreciation of the theory as well as its wide range of usage. It includes the study of integrals, residues, series expansion, and conformality of analytic functions; transforms and their use in differential equations.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To learn the theory of single variable complex functions.
2. To study and appreciate classical results such as Cauchy integral theorem, residue theorem, fundamental theorem of algebra and Picard’s Theorem.
3. To prepare further study on subjects such as harmonic analysis and complex geometry.
courses.course_syllabus: The course is intended to provide an introduction to the analysis and applications of analytic functions on the complex plane. Emphasis will be placed on the understanding and appreciation of the theory as well as its wide range of usage. It includes the study of integrals, residues, series expansion, and conformality of analytic functions; transforms and their use in differential equations.
courses.required_readings: Complex variables and applications (9th edition by Brown and Churchill)
courses.recommended_readings:
* Complex Analysis (Elias Stein)
* Complex Analysis: an introduction to the theory of analytic (Lars Ahlfors)

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Mathematics for Logistics
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course provides the basic mathematical tools for logistics. Topics include: linear and nonlinear programming, resource allocation problem, shortest route problem, inventory and production problem, cargo loading problem, equipment replacement problem, reliability problem, max flow problem, decision tree analysis, production theory, maintenance and reliability theory.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• gain an understanding of the general concepts of the basic theory and algorithms behind linear and integer linear programming.
• learn a method of analyzing a problem by constructing, solving and interpreting the solution(s) of a linear optimization problem.
courses.course_syllabus: This course provides the basic mathematical tools for logistics. Topics may include linear and nonlinear programming, resource allocation problem, shortest route problem, inventory and production problems, cargo loading problems, equipment replacement problems, reliability problems, max flow problems, decision tree analysis, production theory, maintenance, and reliability theory.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by the course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Operations Research: An Introduction by H.F. Taha
2. Introduction to Operations Research by F.S. Hillier and G.J. Lieberman
3. Linear and Nonlinear Programming by D.G. Luenberger and Y.Y. Ye
4. Introduction to Linear Optimization by D. Bertsimas and J.N. Tsitsiklis

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Optimization and Modeling
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree Programme in Mathematics. The course provides an introduction to theory and numerical methods for optimization and modeling.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• understand the general concepts of the basic theory and algorithms behind unconstrained optimization problems in R^n.
• get familiar with Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions for inequality constrained optimization problems and using Lagrange multipliers to solve equality constrained optimization problems.
• convert various problems into optimization problems, identify whether the optimization problem will be linear or nonlinear, select appropriate solution methods and interpret results appropriately.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is an introductory course on optimization and modeling. Topics will be chosen from, but not limited to, unconstrained optimization, set-constrained optimization, convex optimization, constrained optimization problems with equality constraints, constrained optimization problems with inequality constraints, duality, numerical methods for optimization and selected applications.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by the course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. An Introduction to Optimization, E. K. P. Chong and S. H. Zak, John Wiley & Sons.
2. Linear and Nonlinear Programming, D. G. Luenberger and Y. Ye, Springer.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Financial Mathematics
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is an introductory course on Financial Mathematics. Topics include probability, hedging, arbitrage, vanilla options, binomial models, the Black-Scholes formula, exotic options, Monte Carlo methods and binomial methods.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To provide students with a good understanding of financial mathematics, as well as the methods and techniques used in the area to model and analyse financial data.
2. To provide experience of practical applications of mathematics, including mathematical modelling, probability theories and differential equations, in financial modelling.
3. To develop students' ability to critically analyse various financial models for different practical applications.
courses.course_syllabus: The course is an introductory course on Financial Mathematics. Topics include probability, hedging, arbitrage, vanilla options, binomial models, the Black-Scholes formula, exotic options, Monte Carlo methods and binomial methods.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by the course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Options, Futures, and Other Derivatives, by Hull, J.
2. Financial Mathematics, Derivatives and Structured Products, by Chan, R., Guo, Y., Lee, S.T., and Li, X.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Calculus of Variations
courses.description: Extremal problems from mechanics and geometry; First variations and Euler-Lagrange Equations; Constrained variational problems, Lagrange mulitipliers; Second variations and Jacobi necessary condition for weak extrema; and topics chosen from: Hamiltonian formation, Noether theorem on conservation laws, Weierstrass E-function and strong extrema.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Determine the Euler-Lagrange equations and appropriate boundary conditions and then solve the variational problem
• Appreciate how ideas from calculus can be extended to the infinite dimensional setting to solve many practical problems
• Acquire background knowledge in more advanced topics such as differential geometry, partial differential equations, control theory and convex analysis
courses.course_syllabus: Extremal problems from mechanics and geometry; First variations and Euler-Lagrange Equations; Constrained variational problems, Lagrange mulitipliers; Second variations and Jacobi necessary condition for weak extrema; and topics chosen from: Hamiltonian formation, Noether theorem on conservation laws, Weierstrass E-function and strong extrema.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the teaching materials
courses.recommended_readings:
• Van Brunt, The Calculus of Variations
• Gelfand and Fomin, Calculus of Variations
• Troutman, Variational Calculus and Optimal Control

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Introduction to Inverse Problems
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to inverse problems and their computational techniques.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Understand the sources and the ill-posedness of inverse problems
• Apply various regularization methods to inverse problems
• Use the discrepancy principle to select regularization parameters
• Solve large scale inverse problems by iterative technique
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include ill-posed problems, truncated singular value decompositions, Tikhonov regularizations, total variation regularizations, Landweber iteration, discrepancy principle, conjugate gradient method, and applications to image processing, computerized tomography and PDE parameter identification problems.
courses.required_readings: N.A.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Charles Groetsch, Inverse Problems in the Mathematical Sciences
• Andreas Kirsch, An Introduction to the Mathematical Theory of Inverse Problems
• Jennifier Muller and Samuli Slitanen, Linear and Nonlinear Inverse Problems with Practical Applications

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Financial Analytics
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course focuses on the study of multiple and granular views of the real world’s financial data and use it to gain insight and take action through the lens of statistical/mathematical/computational modelling together with computing software, e.g., MATLAB, Python and/or R. The aim of this course is to provide students with practical skills relating to financial modelling and the quantitative analysis of financial data and issues. Students will become familiar with essential topics/case-studies selected from, but not limited to, including, Mathematical Finance, Portfolio and Risk Management, Optimization Methods in Finance, Financial Forecasting, Numerical and Computational Financial Methods and Financial Management.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Analyze, evaluate, interpret, organize and synthesize information in a practical and quantitative manner.
• Undertake in-depth detailed numerical computation and analysis of financial data and information.
• Undertake an independent analysis of a given data set using MATLAB, Python, and/or R.
• Apply sophisticated financial modelling techniques to critically examine financial statements and opportunities.
• Critically evaluate the findings resulting from the application of financial modelling techniques.
courses.course_syllabus: A broad base of knowledge with in-depth analysis and skills development will be covered, including, Financial Statistics, Financial Securities, Time Series Analysis, The Sharpe Ratio, Markowitz Mean-Variance Optimization, Network Analysis, Cluster Analysis, Trading Strategies and Option Pricing Models and so on.
courses.required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Mark J Bennett,‎ Dirk L Hugen (2016) Financial Analytics with R: Building a Laptop Laboratory for Data Science, Cambridge University Press, 1st Edition, 2016.
• Edward E Williams (2017) Quantitative Financial Analytics: The Path to Investment Profits, World Scientific Publishing Company, 1st Edition, 2017.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Computational Mathematics
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to computational mathematics and their applications.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to

- understand the basics in computational mathematics,

- apply various mathematical methods to solve practical applications,

- solve large scale problems by iterative techniques.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include ill-posed problems, least-squares problems, singular value decompositions, regularization techniques, discrepancy principle, classical iterative techniques, projection methods, Arnoldi methods, Krylov subspace methods, conjugate gradient methods, GMRES methods, and applications to image processing, computerized tomography and PDE parameter identification problems.
courses.required_readings: N.A.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Charles Groetsch, Inverse Problems in the Mathematical Sciences

• Andreas Kirsch, An Introduction to the Mathematical Theory of Inverse Problems

• Jennifier Muller and Samuli Slitanen, Linear and Nonlinear Inverse Problems with Practical Applications

• Lloyd N. Trefethen and David Bau III, Numerical Linear Algebra

• Yousef Saad, Iterative Methods for Sparse Linear Systems

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Econometric Principles and Data Analysis
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course is focused on the importation of mathematical and statistical concepts, theories, methods and limitations into economic and data science and provides an overview of econometric methods and data analysis that allows analysts to better understand their economic/business landscape and to improve their ability to make sound economic/business forecasts. Through hands-on exercises based on the information flow of sample data together with available computing software, e.g., MATLAB, Python and/or R programming languages, participants gain knowledge of the practical elements of applied econometric analysis. The overall aim is to sharpen the quantitative, numerical, statistical and analytical skills of participants in dealing with real world examples and issues related to business and economic models.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students will be able to:

• Summarize and describe data through mathematical and statistical techniques and work with data and communicate data-driven findings effectively.

• Develop and use econometric models.

• Have an improved ability to make sound forecasts.

• Use the computing software, e.g., MATLAB, Python and/or R programming languages to perform self-directed empirical analyses.

• Have sharper the quantitative, statistical, numerical and analytical skills.

• Be more effective at translating technical information for key decision-makers.
courses.course_syllabus: A broad base of knowledge with in-depth analysis and skills development will be covered, including, Data Considerations and Managements, Estimation, Regression and Econometrics, Prediction, Experimental Design, Simulation Based Methods (e.g., Bootstrap, Monte Carlo, Indirect Inference), Machine Learning, Data Visualization and so on.
courses.required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
courses.recommended_readings:
• S. Washington, M. Karlaftis, and F. Mannering (2011) Statistical and econometric methods for transportation data analysis, 2nd Edition, Chapman & Hall/CRC, Boca Raton, FL.

• W. Greene (2010). Econometric Analysis, 7th Edition, Pearson.

• J. M. Wooldridge (2012). Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, 5th Edition, Cengage Publications.

• F. Heiss (2016). Using R for introductory econometrics, 1st Edition Dusseldorf.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Probability and Stochastic Analysis
courses.description:
This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course focusses on the rigorous foundation in probability and Markov chains theory with applications in different areas.
No prior knowledge of measure theory is assumed.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion the course, students will be able to

- Understand the basic rigorous theory of probability, for example, expectation, conditional expectation, Central Limit Theorem.

- Apply Markov chain theory to economics, queues and the other topics.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics include:

1. Axioms of probability, conditional probability, random variables and Limit Theorems.

2. Poisson processes, Markov chains, Birth processes and basic theory of martingales.
courses.required_readings: N.A.
courses.recommended_readings:
- S. Ross, A first course in probability, 9th edition, Pearson, (2014).

- J.R. Norris, Markov Chains, Cambridge University Press, (1998).

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Coding Theory
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course aims to introduce a subject of basic theory and practical relevance. Students are expected to have basic knowledge in algebra.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to
1. Design codes with fast encoding, decoding, max transfer of information and max detection of corrections
2. Analyze and design simple linear and cyclic codes
courses.course_syllabus: Topics include: information theory, linear codes, cyclic codes and geometric codes.
courses.required_readings: N.A.
courses.recommended_readings: - Ling San, Xing, Chaoping, Coding Theory - A First Course, Cambridge University Press, (2004)

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Game Theory
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course aims to introduce the principles and techniques of game theory. Students are expected to have knowledge in linear algebra.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this course students will be able to

- Have the basic knowledge in game theory

- Apply game theory to solve problems in different areas, for example, economics and business
courses.course_syllabus: Matrix games, Minimax theorem, optimal strategies, conditional games and applications
courses.required_readings: N.A.
courses.recommended_readings: - P. Morris, Introduction to Game theory, Springer, 1994

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Social and Economic Networks: Theory, Modelling and Computations
courses.description:
This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course provides an overview of quantitative methods appropriate for the data analysis of social and economic networks. Many social and economic activities are embedded in networks because datasets with graph theoretic structure are increasingly available to practical users. Two of the main goals are to study
• how to describe, summarize and visually present network data together with computing software, e.g., MATLAB, Python and/or R and
• formal econometric models of network formation that admit heterogeneity, strategic behavior, and/or dynamics.
Theoretical/statistical/mathematical/computational models and their applications with respect to social and network data from development and labor economics are studied. Essential topics/case-studies are selected from, but not limited to, network formation, peer effects and the social multiplier, social capital and trust, information aggregation in networks, social learning, trading in networks, technology diffusion, job search, and other related topics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Master knowledge and understanding of the current research on the economics of social networks.
• Read research papers in this field.
• Present and critically discuss research papers in this field.
• Have sufficient understanding of open issues to formulate a new research question in this field.
• Undertake an independent analysis of a given data set using MATLAB, Python, and/or R.
courses.course_syllabus: A broad base of knowledge with in-depth analysis and skills development will be covered, including Theoretical and Empirical Background, Peer Effects, Opinion Formation Through Social Learning, Social Capital and Trust, Labor Markets, Favoritism and Political Connections, Firm Networks, Financial Networks, Network Formation: evidence and random graph models, Network Games, and Trading in Networks.
courses.required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
courses.recommended_readings:
• M. O. Jackson (2008). Social and Economic Networks, 1st Edition, Princeton University Press.
• G. Knieps (2015). Network Economics: Principles – Strategies – Competition Policy, 1st Edition, Springer.
• E. D. Kolaczyk, G. Csardi (2014). Statistical Analysis of Network Data with R, 1st Edition, Springer.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Graph Theory and Networks
courses.description:
This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree programme. This course covers some fundamental concepts and principles of graph theory and networks. Transferring some big-data problems to graph models will be introduced. In order to solve such problems, some algorithms of graphs and networks are also discussed.
No prior knowledge is assumed.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion the course, students will be able to
1. Describe the basic concepts, terminologies and properties of graphs.
2. Apply graph algorithms to solve related real life problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics include:
1. Basic concepts and terminologies of graphs and networks
2. Social Network – Centrality and Cliques, Degree of Closeness
3. Ranking Data
4. Shortest Path Algorithm – An application on Social Network
5. Timetabling using Coloring
6. Chinese Postman Problem and Traveling Salesman Problem
courses.required_readings: N.A.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. J.A. Bondy and U.S.R. Murty, Graph Theory with Applications, Macmillan, 1976.
2. G. Chartrand and L. Lesniak, Graphs & Digraphs, 3rd Ed., Chapman & Hall, 1996.
3. J. Clark and D.A. Holton, A First Look at Graph Theory, World Scientific, 1996.
4. J.A. McHugh, Algorithmic Graph Theory, Prentice-Hall, 1990.
5. W.C. Shiu and P.K. Sun, A First Course in Graph Theory, Department of Mathematics, Hong Kong Baptist University, 2014.
6. D.B. West, Introduction To Graph Theory, Prentice-Hall, 1996
7. R.J. Wilson and J.J. Watkins, Graphs, An Introductory Approach, John Wiley and Son, 1990.
8. 邵慰慈，潘建強：基礎離散數學，九章出版社，2005.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Mathematical Image Processing
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree programme. This course gives an introduction on mathematical models and techniques for various image processing tasks. A wide array of topics will be covered, including image restoration (denoising, deblurring), image decomposition, image segmentation, image registration, feature detection, multi-scale image analysis, morphology and so on. Students will become familiar with essential mathematical techniques for imaging tasks, such as image processing in the spatial domain (using gradient, Laplacian, convolution) and frequency domain (using Fourier / wavelet transform). Variational models and PDE-based techniques will be discussed. Deep-learning based techniques will also be explored. Students are expected to have basic knowledge in calculus, linear algebra and MATLAB language. Some background in numerical analysis, Fourier analysis and partial differential equations will be helpful, although the necessary concepts will be discussed as they are used.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students will be able to:

• Understand in-depth the various topics in image processing and the technical difficulties in solving them

• Learn how to use various mathematical models to solve different imaging problems

• Systematically evaluate the performance of different models to solve various imaging problems

• Understand the importance of mathematical imaging for real-world problems
courses.course_syllabus: Cover various topics related to mathematical image processing, including: Basic concepts in digital image processing, Image decomposition and image compression, Image enhancement in the frequency domain, Image enhancement in the spatial domain, Image segmentation, deep learning based techniques for imaging.
courses.required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
courses.recommended_readings: N.A.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Mathematical Theories of Machine Learning
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree Programme in Mathematics. The aim of this course is to introduce the mathematical foundations of and optimization techniques used in machine learning. Both theoretical and numerical approaches for tackling mathematical problems arising from machine learning will be introduced. Learning will be enhanced through software implementation of the computational methods. Topics will be selected from, but not limited to, predictive modeling, classification, neural networks, support vector machines and other related topics. This course assumes no prior experience with programming.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students will be able to:
• understand the major concepts and topics in machine learning,
• master the mathematical formulations of machine learning problems,
• utilize optimization techniques to solve machine learning problems, and
• conduct numerical computations to solve real life problems.
courses.course_syllabus: The mathematical theories and numerical methods for solving various machine learning problems will be covered. Topics will be chosen from, but not limited to, predictive modeling, classification, neural networks, support vector machines and other related topics.
courses.required_readings: This course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
courses.recommended_readings:
- M. P. Deisenroth, A. A. Faisal and C. S. Ong (2020), Mathematics for Machine Learning, Cambridge University Press.
- A. Ghatak (2017), Machine Learning with R, Springer.
- G. Strang (2019), Linear Algebra and Learning from Data, Wellesley-Cambridge Press.
- T. Mitchell (1997), Machine Learning, McGraw Hill.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Mathematical Principles of Artificial Intelligence
courses.description: This course offers a mathematically introductory view of the theoretical foundation and practical approach/technique to artificial intelligence (AI) and serves as a basis for more in depth treatment of specific theories for building AI by means of computing software, e.g., MATLAB, Python and/or R. The aim of this course is to illustrate both the potential and current limitations of different AI techniques with examples from a variety of applications. Students will become familiar with computational models of intelligence behavior as well as essential topics/case-studies selected from, but not limited to, including, Searching Algorithm, Data Mining, Information Retrieval, Computational Neuroscience, Social Intelligence in Computing, and Semantic Analysis.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Identify the historical basis for the latest developments, achievements and designs of AI techniques
• Have knowledge about how to apply AI methods to different types of applications
• Understand the strengths and weaknesses of different AI approaches in terms of human decision-making and learning
• Undertake in-depth detailed numerical computation and algorithms of AI problems
• Undertake an independent analysis of a given AI problem using MATLAB, Python, and/or R.
• Be able to search for literature outlining state-of-the-art within a specific research area
• Be able to critically assess scientific research papers and have experience in presenting scientific work for others
• Be able to design and conduct numerical experiments using AI methods, with emphasis on evaluation and testing
courses.course_syllabus: A broad base of knowledge with in-depth analysis and skills development will be covered, with topics, including, but not limited to, Introduction to AI, Problem Solving through Search, Knowledge Representation and Inference, Representing and Reasoning with Uncertain Knowledge, Decision Making, Learning and Knowledge Acquisition, Natural Language Processing, Financial Services and so on.
courses.required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Russell, S., & Norvig, P. Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach, Prentice-Hall, 2010.
- Pearl, J. Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference. New York: Cambridge University Press, 2000
- Luce, D., & Raiffa, H. Games and Decisions: Introduction and Critical Survey. Dover, 2012.
- Duda, R., Hart, P., & Stork, D. Pattern Classification. New York: Wiley, 2001.
- Tan, P-N., Steinbach, M., & Kumar, V. Introduction to Data Mining. New York: Addison-Wesley, 2004.
- Yang, Q. Intelligent Planning: A Decomposition and Abstraction Based Approach. Berlin: Springer, 1998.
- Grossman, D. A. & Frieder, O. Information Retrieval: Algorithms and Heuristics. Berlin: Springer, 2004.
- Haykin, S. O. Neural Networks and Learning Machines, Pearson, 2009.
- Goodfellow, I., Bengio, Y., & Courville, A. Deep Learning, MIT Press, 2016.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Numerical Linear Algebra and Applications
courses.description: Linear algebra is a fundamental technique that underlies many mathematical disciplines. Numerical linear algebra, in turn, is the basis for scientific computation. This course covers the basic techniques, analysis methods, and details of implementing numerical linear algebra and computing software applications. The course emphasizes the strong link between theoretical concepts, algorithm formulation, and practical implementation, which makes numerical linear algebra widely applicable in various fields. The recent advancements in data science heavily rely on extending concepts from numerical linear algebra, which will also be discussed in the course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students:

• will be proficient in the basic operations of numerical linear algebra

• will understand the significance of the main matrix factorisations

• will be proficient in the construction of linear subspaces

• will be able to determine the computational complexity of numerical linear algebra algorithms;

• will understand the links between numerical linear algebra operations and other fields of data science and their applications

• will be able to implement numerical linear algebra algorithms

完成課程後，學生將：
• 熟練掌握數值線性代數的基本操作；
• 理解主要矩陣分解的重要性；
• 熟練構建線性子空間；
• 能夠確定數值線性代數算法的計算複雜度；
• 理解數值線性代數操作與數據科學其他領域及其應用之間的聯繫；
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is designed for MSc students with a background in mathematics. It covers the fundamentals of matrix algebra, computer arithmetic, conditioning and condition numbers, stability of numerical algorithms, vector and matrix norms, convergent matrices, stability of non-linear systems, sensitivity analysis, singular value decomposition (SVD), algebraic and geometric properties of SVD, least square solutions, Householder matrices and applications, the QR method, the Power method and applications, and the Jacobi method for finding the eigenvalues of a given matrix. The course has wide-ranging applications in fields such as data science, including machine learning, artificial intelligence, data visualization, and business intelligence.

本課程專為具有數學背景的碩士學生設計。內容涵蓋矩陣代數的基礎、計算機算術、條件數和條件數、數值算法的穩定性、向量和矩陣範數、收斂矩陣、非線性系統的穩定性、靈敏度分析、奇異值分解（SVD）、SVD的代數和幾何性質、最小二乘解、豪斯霍爾德矩陣及其應用、QR方法、冪方法及其應用，以及雅可比方法求解給定矩陣的特徵值。該課程在數據科學等領域具有廣泛應用，包括機器學習、人工智能、數據可視化和商業智能。
courses.required_readings:
1. Crista Arangala, Linear Algebra With Machine Learning and Data, CRC Press, 2023.
2. Mark J. DeBonis, Introduction To Linear Algebra - Computation, Application, and Theory, CRC Press, 2022.
3. Biswa Nath Dutta, Numerical Linear Algebra and Applications, SIAM, 2010.
4. William Ford, Numerical Linear Algebra with Applications, Academic Press, 2014.
5. Roger A. Horn and Charles R. Johnson, Matrix Analysis, Cambridge University Press, 1994.
6. Ruriko Yoshida, Linear Algebra and Its Applications with R, CRC Press, 2021.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Markov Chains and Algorithmic Applications
courses.description: This course aims to familiarise students with the theory of Markov Chains and provide an overview of how this theory can be applied to problems in financial mathematics, data science, and network science using different randomised algorithms.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students:

• will understand the basic definitions of Markov chains, compute properties of states, and apply Markov Chains to problems in applied mathematics
• will assess and evaluate the performance of an algorithm on a graph
• will implement various sampling methods efficiently

完成課程後，學生將：
• 理解馬爾可夫鏈的基本定義，計算狀態的性質，並將馬爾可夫鏈應用於應用數學問題
• 評估和評價算法在圖上的性能
• 高效實施各種採樣方法
courses.course_syllabus:
The course aims to introduce the theory of Markov chains, focusing on their applications for scientific computing. We will emphasise the mixing properties of finite-state, discrete-time, reversible Markov chains, which determine how quickly a chain reaches its stationary distribution from any starting state. While this may initially seem simple, it is crucial for analysing Markov Chain Monte Carlo and Hidden Markov models. It also connects to classical questions in statistical physics, numerical integration, randomised algorithms, and combinatorial optimisation. Furthermore, it has applications in distributed computing, large-scale graph mining, text analytics and high-dimensional optimisation.

本課程旨在介紹馬爾可夫鏈的理論，重點關注其在科學計算中的應用。我們將強調有限狀態、離散時間、可逆馬爾可夫鏈的混合性質，這些性質決定了鏈從任何初始狀態到達穩態分佈的速度。雖然這看似簡單，但對於分析馬爾可夫鏈蒙特卡洛和隱馬爾可夫模型至關重要。它還涉及統計物理、數值積分、隨機算法和組合優化中的經典問題。此外，它在分佈式計算、大規模圖挖掘、文本分析和高維優化中也有應用。
courses.required_readings:
1. Liliana Blanco-Castañeda, Viswanathan Arunachalam, Applied Stochastic Modeling, Springer, 2023.
2. Gernot A. Fink, Markov Models for Pattern Recognition From Theory to Application, 2nd edition, 2014.
3. Geoffrey R. Grimmett, David R. Stirzaker, Probability and Random Processes, 3rd edition, Oxford University Press, 2001.
4. Matthew L. Jockers, Rosamond Thalken, Text Analysis with R For Students of Literature, Springer, 2020.
5. John G. Kemeny, J. Laurie Snell, Finite Markov Chains, Springer, 1976.
6. D. Levin, Y. Peres, E. Wilmer, Lecture Notes on Markov Chains and Mixing Times, 2nd edition, AMS, 2017.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Mathematics of Games of Chance
courses.description: This course delves into the mathematical concepts relevant to analysing games of chance. Topics covered include probabilities, odds, house advantages, fairness assessments, variance, risk evaluation, statistical tests for game honesty, optimal strategies, random walks, the gambler’s ruin, the Kelly criterion, and estimating gaming revenue. The course illustrates these concepts using examples from various games, including Lottery, Roulette, Blackjack, Poker, and Bridge.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students will know how to:

• compute the expected value and variance of some popular games of chance
• find optimal strategies for games involving skills

完成課程後，學生將能夠：
• 計算一些流行機會遊戲的期望值和方差
• 找到涉及技能遊戲的最佳策略
courses.course_syllabus:
The course aims to introduce the mathematical analysis of games of chance, focusing on their applications to probabilistic computing. Selected topics include conditional expectation, discrete martingales, Markov chains, house advantage, craps, video poker, gambler’s ruin, slots, and betting systems, which encompass strategic skills. This course also includes a scientific computation component.

本課程旨在介紹機會遊戲的數學分析，重點關注其在概率計算中的應用。選定的主題包括條件期望、離散鞅、馬爾可夫鏈、莊家優勢、擲骰子、視頻撲克、賭徒破產、老虎機和投注系統，這些都包含了戰略技能。本課程還包括科學計算部分。
courses.required_readings:
1. Mark Bollman, Basic Gambling Mathematics: The Numbers Behind the Neon, CRC Press, 2021.
2. Richard A. Epstein, The Theory of Gambling and Statistical Logic, Academic Press, 2013.
3. Stewart N. Ethier, The Doctrine of Chances: Probabilistic Aspects of Gambling, Springer, 2010.
4. Edward W Packel, The Mathematics of Games and Gambling, The Mathematical Association of America, 1981.
5. David G. Taylor, Games, Gambling, and Probability, CRC Press, 2021.
6. David G. Taylor, The Mathematics of Games, CRC Press, 2015.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Mathematics of Multivariate Data
courses.description: This course introduces the mathematics of multivariate data analysis. The course builds on the concepts and skills developed in multivariate data analysis and methodology using R.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students should be able to tackle modern multivariate problems by:
• selecting the appropriate methods and justifying your choices;
• implementing these methods programmatically (using, say, the R programming language) and evaluating your results; and
• explaining your results to a researcher outside of statistics.

完成課程後，學生應能夠通過以下方式解決現代多變量問題：
• 選擇適當的方法並證明您的選擇；
• 使用編程方式（例如R編程語言）實施這些方法並評估您的結果；
• 向統計學以外的研究人員解釋您的結果。
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics include a review of some important concepts (likelihood, quadratic forms, random vectors and matrices, multiple regression and variable selection), an overview of classical multivariate statistics, multivariate regression, dimensionality reduction, discriminant analysis and classification. Additional topics will be selected from modern statistical learning methodology. This course also includes a scientific computation component.

主題包括一些重要概念的回顧（似然性、二次型、隨機向量和矩陣、多重回歸和變量選擇）、經典多變量統計概述、多變量回歸、降維、判別分析和分類。其他主題將從現代統計學習方法中選擇。本課程還包括科學計算部分。
courses.required_readings:
1. Richard A. Johnson, Dean W. Wichern, Applied Multivariate Statistical Analysis (6th Edition), Pearson, 2015.
2. Hardle Wolfgang, Leopold Simar. Applied multivariate statistical analysis. Heidelberg: Springer Berlin Heidelberg, 2012.
3. Hastie Trevor, Robert Tibshirani, J. H. Friedman. The elements of statistical learning: Data mining, inference, and prediction. New York, NY: Springer New York, 2009.
4. D. Mirman. Growth curve analysis and visualization using R. CRC Press, 2016.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Foundation of Advanced Mathematics
courses.description: The course is intended to build a solid foundation for the students on the essential topics and the rigorous reasoning of mathematics. It includes the discussion of logic, sets and functions, cardinality and countability, basic number theory, real number and limits. (Not for undergraduate students, students in the MSc. Programme in Mathematics, and students who have taken MAT/MATH5011, 5012, 5031, 5032, 5051, 570S, 6xxx and 7xxx.)
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• Read and write mathematical statements.
• Prove elementary mathematical results.
• Understand and apply elementary results in advanced mathematics.
• Appreciate the usefulness of rigorous reasoning in mathematics.
courses.required_readings: Suggested by instructor.
courses.recommended_readings:
• I. Stewart, D. Tall, The Foundation of Mathematics (Second Edition)
• K. G. Binmore, Foundations of Analysis: a straightforward introduction (Book 1 Logic, Sets and Numbers)
• W. Barnier, N. Feldman, Introduction to Advanced Mathematics (Second Edition);
• G. Chartrand, A. D. Polimeni, P. Zhang, Mathematical Proofs: A Transition to Advanced Mathematics

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Differential Equation and Linear Algebra
courses.description: The course is intended to provide an amalgamated treatment of Differential Equations and Linear Algebra. Emphasis will be placed on algebraic intuition and geometric visualization, together with illustrations of applications. (Not for undergraduate students, students in the MSc. Programme in Mathematics, and students who have taken MAT/MATH5011, 5012, 5031, 5032, 5051, 570S, 6xxx and 7xxx.)
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MSc Programme in Math Education.
Undergraduate students, students in the MSc. Programme in Mathematics, and students who have taken MAT/MATH5011, 5012, 5031, 5032, 5051, 570S, 6xxx and 7xxx are not allowed to take the course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To learn the basic concepts and theory in linear algebra.

2. To learn the technique of solving ordinary differential equations of first and second order.

3. To apply the theory in linear algebra to solve linear system of differential equations.
courses.course_syllabus: Topics includes matrices, determinant, inverse of matrices, first order ordinary differential equations, second order linear differential equations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization of matrices, Jordan normal forms, system of differential equations.
courses.required_readings: Edwards & Penney, Differential Equations and Linear Algebra; Pearson Education International.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Finite Mathematics and Mathematical Programming
courses.description: The course is intended to discuss mathematical methods frequently applied in managerial, business and social studies. It starts with a review of Linear Equations, then the main topics are selected from Linear Programming and Simplex Method, Counting and Probability, Game Theory, Basic Finance Mathematics, Mathematical Modelling. (Not for undergraduate students, students in the MSc. Programme in Mathematics, and students who have taken MAT/MATH5011, 5012, 5031, 5032, 5051, 570S, 6xxx and 7xxx.)
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To learn basic concepts and algorithm related to elementary matrix algebra
2. To learn how to apply elementary matrix algebra algorithms to Simple Method
3. To learn elementary Linear Programming via (i) graphical method, (ii) Simplex Method
4. To learn elementary concepts in 2 person game theory via graphical methods and extensions of 2-peson game theory.
5. To learn elementary counting arguments preparing for discrete probability theory
6. To learn concepts and basic computational methods in discrete probability theory
7. To learn elementary notions in finance, e.g. simple Interest, compound Interest, annuity, future value.
8. To learn some examples of real-applications of the above-mentioned topics, viz. examples in finance or social sciences.
courses.course_syllabus: As stated in the course description, the course syllabus will comprise selection from the list of learning outcomes above. Main focus of the course will be on two topics, viz. matrix algebra, their algorithms on one hand and counting and its application to probability on the other. As for financial mathematics, Game Theory and modeling --- these will be viewed as applications of the preceding two main topics.
courses.required_readings: Chosen note or typed notes by the instructor.
courses.recommended_readings: Ross, Sheldon: Topics in Discrete and Finite Mathematics.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Advanced Geometry
courses.description: This course mainly introduces students to the fundamental concepts of analytic geometry and vector geometry. It covers topics such as plane analytic geometry, Cartesian and Polar coordinates, transformation of coordinates, pairs of straight lines, circles, conic sections, direction cosines, direction ratios, planes, parametric equations, and vectors. Additional topics such as Euclidean Geometry, Non-Euclidean Geometry, Transformational Geometry, Projective Geometry, Geometric Symmetries, or Finite Geometry may be included. (Not for undergraduate students, students in the MSc. Programme in Mathematics, and students who have taken MAT/MATH5011, 5012, 5031, 5032, 5051, 570S, 6xxx and 7xxx.)
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students will be able to:
1. Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental concepts in analytic geometry and vector geometry
2. Apply knowledge of analytic geometry and vector geometry to solve mathematical problems
3. Appreciate and understand how to develop analytic geometry based on Euclidean axioms
4. Utilize geometry principles and techniques to model and solve real-world problems
5. Communicate mathematical ideas and solutions effectively, both orally and in written form, using appropriate mathematical language and notation
6. Get a glimpse of other geometries, such as hyperbolic geometry, elliptic geometry, absolute geometry, projective geometry, geometric symmetries, or finite geometry.

完成本課程後，學生將能夠：
1. 全面理解解析幾何和向量幾何的基本概念。
2. 應用解析幾何和向量幾何的知識解決數學問題。
3. 欣賞並理解如何基於歐幾里德公理發展解析幾何。
4. 運用幾何原理和技巧對現實世界問題進行建模和解決。
5. 以口頭和書面形式有效地傳達數學思想和解決方案，使用適當的數學語言和符號。
6. 簡要了解其他幾何學領域，例如雙曲幾何，橢圓幾何，射影幾何，幾何對稱性或有限幾何。
courses.course_syllabus:
The main focus of this course is to explore two topics: analytic geometry and vector geometry. Based on these, we will discuss selected topics in Euclidean geometry, non-Euclidean geometries, projective geometry, etc. in an introductory way.

本課程主要探索解析幾何和向量幾何。此外，還可能包括歐式幾何、非歐幾何、變換幾何、射影幾何、幾何對稱或有限幾何。
courses.required_readings: Chosen note or typed notes by the instructor.
courses.recommended_readings: Stillwell, John: The Four Pillars of Geometry.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Introduction to Combinatorics
courses.description: This course is an introduction of combinatorics, which includes basic counting techniques, pigeonhole principle, generating function. Further topics will be chosen from probability theory, graph theory, partition theory, geometric combinatorics, game theory and design theory.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• understand the fundamental concepts of combinatorics
• use techniques acquired in this course to solve application problems
• encompass an appreciation of the interplay between theory and practice
courses.course_syllabus:
Basic counting techniques, Permutation and Combination, Binomial theorem, Pigeonhole principle, Inclusion-exclusion principle, Recurrence relations, Generating function
Additional topics may include:
Probability theory, Graph theory, Planar graph, Eulerian Path, Partition theory, Geometric combinatorics, Game theory, Design theory

基本計數技巧、排列及組合、二項式定理、鴿巢原理、排容原理、遞迴關係、生成函數
其他課題可能包括:
概率論、圖論、平面圖、歐拉路徑、分拆理論、幾何組合學、對策論、設計理論

courses.recommended_readings:

• George E. Martin (2001), Counting: The Art of Enumerative Combinatorics, Springer Science & Business Media.

courses.subject: MMAT
courses.title: Mathematics Enhancement for Teachers
courses.description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics Education. This course aims to provide a solid mathematical background for teaching professionals.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are able to:
• develop a deep understanding of mathematical concepts for teaching in schools
• use mathematical language, notations, terminology, logic and reasoning precisely
• appreciate the beauty of mathematics to have motivation in teaching
courses.course_syllabus: This course is a formal introduction of school mathematics that provides a more rigorous background for teaching mathematics. Topics include numbers and operations, college algebra, geometry and measurement, trigonometry, probability and statistics.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Thomas H. Parker, Scott J. Baldridge (2004), Elementary Mathematics for Teachers, Sefton-Ash Publishing
• Thomas H. Parker, Scott J. Baldridge (2008), Elementary Geometry for Teachers, Sefton-Ash Publishing
